channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Muhammad Yunus to Head Bangladesh Interim Government
item.description: The new government was being formed a day after Bangladesh’s longtime leader, facing fierce protests, fled the country.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Hamas Names an Architect of Oct. 7 Attacks as New Political Leader
item.description: Hamas announced that Yahya Sinwar would take over as the group’s political leader after the assassination of Ismail Haniyeh in Iran.

item.title: OpenAI is suffering an exodus of senior talent
item.description: The newest departures leave OpenAI with only three of its 11 original cofounders.

item.title: X, Owned by Elon Musk, Brings Antitrust Suit Accusing Advertisers of a Boycott
item.description: The company claimed that members of the Global Alliance for Responsible Media coordinated to dissuade brands from advertising on X.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Leader Fled Just Ahead of an Angry Crowd, Urged by Family to Go
item.description: As masses of people converged, angry at the killing of protesters, Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina insisted that she could hold on, which military leaders said would mean spilling far more blood.

item.title: 5 ways a Harris-Walz win could reshape U.S. health care
item.description: Big changes could be coming, according to policy experts.

item.title: E.P.A. Pulls Pesticide Dacthal From the Market Over Health Concerns
item.description: The herbicide, used widely on crops including broccoli and onions, can cause low birth weight and impaired brain development, regulators said.

item.title: Muhammad Yunus to Head Bangladesh Interim Government
item.description: The new government was being formed a day after Bangladesh’s longtime leader, facing fierce protests, fled the country.

item.title: An interest rate cut won’t fix the housing crisis, Moody’s economist says
item.description: Rate cuts will help, but there’s still a shortfall of close to 2 million homes in the country, according to Moody’s.

item.title: He Stands Out in a ‘Sea of Elites and Strivers’: Our Writers on What Tim Walz Brings to the Ticket
item.description: Opinion asked eight columnists and contributors to weigh in on how much the Minnesota governor will help Harris against Trump.

item.title: E.P.A. Pulls Pesticide Dacthal From the Market Over Health Concerns
item.description: The herbicide, used widely on crops including broccoli and onions, can cause low birth weight and impaired brain development, regulators said.

item.title: In Tim Walz, Kamala Harris gets a labor champion who can still appeal to critical heartland voters
item.description: The Minnesota governor has passed sweeping labor reform laws in his second term, earning the endorsements of UAW President Shawn Fein and Senator Bernie Sanders.

item.title: How the Google Antitrust Ruling May Influence Tech Competition
item.description: Nearly a quarter-century after Microsoft lost a similar case, a judge’s decision that Google abused a monopoly in internet search is likely to have major ripple effects.

item.title: Venezuela’s Strongman Was Confident of Victory. Then Came the Shock.
item.description: Venezuela’s government believed its control of all levers of power would give the country’s authoritarian president an Election Day victory. A rebellion by its supporters undid the plan.

item.title: How an obscure Japanese yen trade sparked a global market meltdown—and why the worst could be yet to come
item.description: Financial experts explain the Japanese yen carry trade, a Wall Street favorite that’s beginning to unwind.
